data.content:
In case you missed it, all links on Mastodon count as 23 characters towards your limit, no matter how many characters the link really is.

So, you don't need to use link shorteners on Mastodon as they won't actually affect the link's length.

Mastodon does this because it's better for everyone's privacy to avoid link shortener services, it means people can see what they're clicking on, and the link won't stop working if the shortener service shuts down.

More info at:

‚û°Ô∏è https://fedi.tips/you-dont-need-link-shorteners-on-mastodon/

descendants.content: @feditips This was a good design decision for accessibility & usability. We do complain sometimes about Mastodon's support for #a11y, but there are many small decisions like this that demonstrate people did *want* to do the right think.

account.note:
Did you know some people still have "webmaster" as a title? Wild!
he/him
Following because I followed you may not be a wise use of your time.

descendants.content: @FeralRobots @feditips whats a11y?

account.note:
#Artist, aspiring #animator, #Undertale fan.
They/them

fields.name: Pronouns
fields.value: They/them

descendants.content:
@IamAcand @feditips
If you follow the tag you'll find posts about digital accessibility. 'a11y' is a #numeronym for 'accessibility'. It dates back to 140 character Twitter & it's how most folks posting about accessibility tag their posts.

Numeronyms use the first & last characters of a term to bookend a numeral representing the number of characters in between. E.g. 'accessibility' reduced to 'a11y', which is a big deal if your trying to communicate in coherent 140 or 280 char chunks.

account.note:
Did you know some people still have "webmaster" as a title? Wild!
he/him
Following because I followed you may not be a wise use of your time.

descendants.content: @FeralRobots @IamAcand @feditips (genuine curiosity) is a11y readable in a coherent way by screen readers? Does it pronounce it like a-eleven-y or a-one-one-y or something? I mean presumably people within a community that uses accessibility features regularly just kinda recognize that tag either way but I wondered how it is read. I‚Äôm trying to learn more about these things so thanks for your earlier explanation!

@svkeban
I think it generally reads as "a 1 1 y" - & that's how a lot of accessibility folks used to read it, too. In principle, that's not great, but at this point it's widely enough understood that I don't think accessibility professionals give it a lot of thought.
@IamAcand @feditips

account.note:
Did you know some people still have "webmaster" as a title? Wild!
he/him
Following because I followed you may not be a wise use of your time.

descendants.content: @FeralRobots @IamAcand @feditips Thanks! It‚Äôs so interesting how language evolves (including terminology and hashtags). I‚Äôll have to remember this if I see this out in the wild, I feel certain I‚Äôve seen ‚Äúa11y‚Äù used before in posts and didn‚Äôt know what it was so it‚Äôs great to learn.

@FeralRobots @IamAcand @feditips The 140/280 character limit is fundamentally incompatible with the coherent communication unless the idea you‚Äôre trying to convey just happens to incredibly simple and short. If all you do is post a headline and the relevant link to a news article and a blog post, that limitation won‚Äôt really matter very much. Unfortunately, people started using Twitter as a discussion platform, so no wonder why we ended up with a dumpster fire. Oh, and the gasoline algorithm didn‚Äôt really help, but it did increase engagement, so I guess it worked, if viewed from a certain angle.

@FeralRobots
(Only half jokingly) Since the character count is only "approximately & roughly", why restrict the length of the post to 500 for posting; instead allow poster to exceed 500 to "finish" the sentence. Also there is no need to use things like "a11y", but spell it out fully.
@IamAcand @feditips

descendants.content:
@aswath
Where's the 'approximate' & 'rough' language coming from? If that's actually written into documentation, it should be struck - the limit is deterministic. It could *appear* rough or approximate because things don't take up the same number of characters they appear to (e.g. all URLs being 23 chars*), but AFAIK it's a hard limit.
_
*also I've been told but haven't verified that each emoji eats 2 chars?

@IamAcand @feditips

account.note:
Did you know some people still have "webmaster" as a title? Wild!
he/him
Following because I followed you may not be a wise use of your time.

descendants.content:
@FeralRobots
That is my editorial add-on. Empirically it seems to me that my Mastodon server delivers posts longer than 500 chars. From this thread I understand that if the text is say 472 chars, but the linked URL is however long, the post will be accepted, even though the actual char count is > 500 chars. So am suggesting why not a bit more permissive and allow a few grace chars ssi the author can finish the sentence. That was my point.
@IamAcand @feditips

descendants.content:
@aswath
Oh our server (mastodon.social) ABSOLUTELY delivers posts longer than 500 chars üòÜ . That's an artifact of federation & it's a bona-fide feature (as in, NOT-'feature-not-a-bug'). It's because there are plenty of posts sourced from other servers which allow posts of greater or even indefinite length. (Some also allow linked text & basic character-scope HTML formatting.)

But it's not gonna allow YOU (or anyone else on our instance) to post at more than 500 char.
@IamAcand @feditips

descendants.content:
@feditips

Nearly everyone using link shorteners are not doing it to save character count.

Instead they are people who perceive themselves as 'influencers' trying to side-step the fact Mastodon does not give you 'engagement' metrics outside of 'likes' and 'boosts'. They are using them as trackers.

And they are violating a social contract unique to the Fediverse. It kind of pisses me off.

descendants.content: @feditips @jackwilliambell and one other reason is for people who use third party services like @socialchamp to post across different services. These services give you 500 characters to play with, including every character in a url

descendants.content:
@florida_ted @feditips

Exactly. I ranted about this very subject the other day ‚Äì my contention is the majority of people on the #Fediverse are wise to this kind of shit and that, on the whole, this isn't the best environment for 'influencers'.

(And I like it that way.)

> https://rustedneuron.com/@jackwilliambell/110674395451024788

card.title: Jack William Bell (@jackwilliambell@rustedneuron.com)
card.description:
Sorry to say this, but the #Fediverse might not be the best place for you if you think you are an 'Influencer'. 

Why? Because the people here are hyper-aware of privacy issues and if you are an 'Influencer' you need statistics and metrics to prove your reach and clout. Otherwise you are just one of the hoi polloi.

I'm bringing this up because I am noticing the extent to which those who obviously consider themselves 'Influencers' are resorting to things like URL shorteners lately.

[contd]

descendants.content:
@jackwilliambell @florida_ted @feditips

Please get over yourselves. A HUGE number of Mastodon users are new within the last couple of years and simply. don't. know. this information. Myself included.

Your indignation and instant labeling of shorteners as "influencers" shows a real lack of empathy and is frankly quite insulting.

THIS is why people get frustrated at the older users--you are so quick to judge and disparage. I love this platform but spewing stuff like this is infuriating.

descendants.content:
@jackwilliambell @feditips

Mastodon totally gives engagement metrics. Anytime you own a domain/instance you can get whatever metrics you like.

I suggest anyone wanting to 'track' / have standard analytics to run their own instance.

Also, did we sign a social contract? I didn't sign anything.

descendants.content:
@jackwilliambell @feditips

if you own the instance that was my understanding.

But honestly open to be wrong.

This reddit post https://www.reddit.com/r/Mastodon/comments/z79u8z/analytics_but_for_mastodon/ seems to agree, and so does the marketing materials here
https://www.analytodon.com/

I haven't seen any of this with my own eyes. And searched with a bias. But... in general I've always thought if you control the input/output then you get a lot more stats. I mean, every person has to request media files from you, if you own the instance. If you make resources unique you could have more fun.

card.title: Analytics, but for Mastodon
card.description: Among many other things, I run social media accounts for large organizations. Many of these large organizations are moving to Mastodon. These...

descendants.content:
@INIT6 @feditips

Nope. First, the only way you can know if someone clicked on a link on a page, whether or not your server sent that page, is if there is either (a) Javascript that sends a message to the server or (b) the link is actually to your server and the server forwards to the correct link while logging the request. (The latter is how URL shorteners work.) And Mastodon does not instrument links that way.

Second, well ‚Äì read the ActivityPub specs and we'll talk. OK?

Honestly, if you own your short domain name, I don't mind you doing some analytics upon clicking - it's as much as browser allows anyway and no third-party entity in-between that could misuse this data, it's just between you and me.

Whether something is owned by third party or not is a real discerning factor.

descendants.content: @feditips let me rephrase that question: Would I be able to write a full article starting with https:// and separate words using underscores?

@fabeltjeskrant

You can try it yourself by replying to me, but usually Mastodon will not show the full link if it is beyond a certain length.

For example, the link here should appear abbreviated on most interfaces and apps: https://thisisaverylongsubdomaintogiveanexample.example.com

If the link is abbreviated, you can preview the whole link by hovering the mouse over it or long-pressing it on a touchscreen.

descendants.content: @feditips I see. That‚Äôs a shame. I guess I want to use Mastodon as a blogging platform instead of a microblogging platform. I had an account on qoto.org because they support 64k characters, but I cannot find a client, not counting their own web client, that supports messages this size. It used to be that clients honor the servers capabilities, so I would expect a client to support longer than 500 character messages, but AFAIU there is a recent but that has broken this behaviour?

@fabeltjeskrant

You don't have to use Mastodon to publish on Mastodon.

Mastodon is part of the Fediverse, and there are lots of other Fediverse platforms you can use instead.

For example, you can turn any independently hosted WordPress blog into a Fediverse server, and authors on that blog can be followed from Mastodon.

You can choose to display blog articles either in full, or as excerpts with a link, or just as links.

More info here:

https://fedi.tips/wordpress-turning-your-blog-into-a-fediverse-server/

descendants.content:
@fabeltjeskrant

Another option is Friendica, where there's effectively no character limit on posts. It is also part of the Fediverse, and Friendica servers federate with Mastodon servers:

https://fedi.tips/friendica-a-flexible-fediverse-server-type-with-long-posts/

Or Write Freely, a Medium-style platform:

https://fedi.tips/writefreely-long-form-writing-platform-for-the-fediverse/

descendants.content:
@feditips
We came from Fakebook and at first we lamented the 500 #characterLimit.

Now we like it.

We do thinks like combining posts sometimes but generally we see it as a service to others to try and keep things a bit tight.

We understand that Epicyon has a longer character limit, also. It has the added benefits of not requiring javascript and is designed to work with I2P network also with no fuss.

@fabeltjeskrant

descendants.content: @tsyum @unexpectedteapot @feditips QR codes can use fewer pixels and are less prone to errors if the content is shorter. Having said that, you should always include a human readable link and concise links are easier to use.

account.note: Lefty living in the French Quarter of New Orleans. I have a painting of Kurt Vonnegut over my bed to remind me every morning that we're just here to fart around.

descendants.content: @tsyum @feditips free open-source software, like: https://envs.sh/ (it is based on https://github.com/envs-net/0x0 a fork of https://git.0x0.st/mia/0x0) but it requires using a command-line to create a shortened URL.

descendants.content:
@AudraTran

Yeah, a lot of people don't realise that all links on Twitter, Reddit etc automatically flow through shorteners so that they can track who is clicking on what.

Twitter even disguise this by making a link seem original, but it's actually going through a shortener. (If you're on a desktop browser, hover your mouse over a link on Twitter and look in the bottom left corner, you'll see it's always a t.co address.)

Posting hints and tips about Mastodon and the Fediverse üåç

There are lots of answers to common questions about Mastodon and the Fediverse on my website at https://fedi.tips. If you can't find your answer, @ or DM me and I will try to help! There's no such thing as a silly question!
